schedule.Event description: The intersection between policy and sustainability is a critical area of consideration for addressing contemporary societal challenges, particularly in the context of environmental, social, and economic sustainability.
schedule.Company/Affiliation: School of International and Public Affairs
schedule.Bio: As Senior Fellow at the Initiative for Policy Dialogue (IPD) at Columbia University, I undertake research and bringing research results to policy analysis and advice on issues of economic development and globalization. Co-chair along with Joe Stiglitz, IPD's Task Forces on Africa and Industrial Policy. Teach graduate level courses at Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs (SIPA).

schedule.Event description: Git, VSCode, Tooling, package managers, and Teamwork

A discussion of recent trends in the incidence of mental health illnesses among Americans as well as systemic issues with access to mental health care, especially for young adults and children. I’ll also discuss why treatments for some severe conditions remain elusive.
schedule.Bio: Caitlin Gilbert is a Well+Being data reporter at The Washington Post. Before joining The Post, she worked as a U.S.-based data journalist at the Financial Times, where she covered many topics, including the economy, politics and abortion access across the country. She earlier worked as a visual journalist at Reuters. She received her PhD in neuroscience and genomics from Rockefeller University.

schedule.Event name/title: Workshop - Backend: Creating the mitochondria of your web app
schedule.Hosts: David Li Adheesh Kadiresan Julia Ding
schedule.Event description: Intro to Backend Design with endpoints, NoSQL with MongoDB

schedule.Event name/title: Coding on deadline - responsibility and process when building projects in a newsroom
schedule.Event description: Katie Marriner will primarily focus on the politics-related stories she's worked on and how it ties into the political track at DevFest.
schedule.Bio: Katie designs and develops interactives for 538, specifically focusing on data visualizations to help explain and do deep dives into political data. Before that, her focus was on analyzing and visualizing economic and financial data for MarketWatch.

schedule.Event name/title: Workshop - Frontend: I came, I saw, I designed
schedule.Event description: Intro to React, Next.js, HTML, JavaScript, TypeScript and CSS

schedule.Event name/title: Graduate from OpenAI to Open Source: 12 best practices for distilling smaller models from GPT
schedule.Event description: As LLMs become increasingly capable and integral to various applications, the need for more efficient, smaller counterparts has never been more pronounced. Model distillation has emerged as a popular option to balance capability with cost-effectiveness and speed. The advice in this talk draws from our experience distilling language models at Google and Predibase, combined with any SLM/LLM research we could find on the topic.
schedule.Bio: Justin is an Engineering Lead at Predibase, a machine learning infrastructure startup that specializes in small language models (SLMs) and adapter-based fine tuning and serving. Prior, Justin was a Research Engineer at Google, primarily focused on natural language generation and deep learning. Justin's primary interests are in NLP, deep learning, music, and the intersection of computer science and human creativity. While at Columbia, Justin co-founded Columbia Pops and was a board member of ADI.

schedule.Event name/title: Workshop - AI/ML: Are you smarter than a recommendation system?
Lightning Talks: So You Wanna Be a HACKER?
schedule.Event description: A Series of Previous Hacks and the Brainstorming Process

schedule.Bio: Chris Wiggins is an associate professor of applied mathematics at Columbia University and the Chief Data Scientist at The New York Times. At Columbia he is a founding member of the executive committee of the Data Science Institute, and of the Department of Systems Biology, and is affiliated faculty in Statistics. He is a co-founder and co-organizer of hackNY (http://hackNY.org), a nonprofit which since 2010 has organized once a semester student hackathons and the hackNY Fellows Program, a structured summer internship at NYC startups. Prior to joining the faculty at Columbia he was a Courant Instructor at NYU (1998-2001) and earned his PhD at Princeton University (1993-1998) in theoretical physics. He is a Fellow of the American Physical Society and is a recipient of Columbia’s Avanessians Diversity Award.

schedule.Event description: Join our ADI alumni to chat about life at Columbia and beyond!
schedule.Bio: Justin is an Engineering Lead at Predibase, a machine learning infrastructure startup that specializes in small language models (SLMs) and adapter-based fine tuning and serving. Prior, Justin was a Research Engineer at Google, primarily focused on natural language generation and deep learning. Justin's primary interests are in NLP, deep learning, music, and the intersection of computer science and human creativity. While at Columbia, Justin co-founded Columbia Pops and was a board member of ADI.

From being the first engineering hire in a startup to a tech lead at Google, Polina has worked at companies in varying stages of development and sizes. After brief stints in front-end and data engineering, Polina is now focusing on distributed backend systems.

schedule.Company/Affiliation: Lead Product Manager, Teachers Pay Teachers
schedule.Bio:
Will Essilfie is a technologist and product leader passionate about building community-powered products. He is a Lead Product Manager at TPT, the world's largest marketplace for PreK-12 resources, where he leads teams focused on user acquisition, seller tooling, and search relevance systems to help teachers connect with one another and share their collective wisdom. Prior to TPT, Will worked as a Product Manager at RangeMe, where he helped drive Marketplace Health, and as a Data Scientist at Facebook, where he supported women in emerging markets by helping them find safe communities.
Will holds a BA in Computer Science with a concentration in Business Management from Columbia University.

schedule.Company/Affiliation: Head of Development Innovation, Regeneron; Lecturer in Population Health Sciences, Weill Cornell Medicine
schedule.Bio: Henry Wei, MD heads Global Development Innovation at Regeneron, aimed at accelerating clinical trials & research. Dr. Wei previously worked at Google, the White House, Aetna, and McKinsey. Dr Wei has co-authored patents on AI in healthcare and on real-world data and drug safety. He earned his MD at Cornell, his graduate and undergraduate degrees at Harvard University with published research on sleep & circadian rhythms neuroelectrophysiology. In 2012, Henry Wei and Nayan Jain won a long-form global hackathon, the Health 2.0 World Developers' Cup, with MedTuner, an NLP-driven clinical decision support AI and personal social media companion.

Ansh has been a software engineer at Jane Street Capital for the last one and a half years. Prior to that, he was a Computer Science and Math double major with a minor in Economics from the University of Texas at Austin, where he also was very involved in the local hackathon HackTX. In his free time, he enjoys playing music on various string instruments, expanding his gaming collection, and losing at ping pong.

schedule.Company/Affiliation: Microsoft AI & Emerging Technologies Business Development Analyst
schedule.Bio: As an AI & Emerging Technologies Business Development Analyst at Microsoft, I work with global partners to accelerate the adoption of AI and cloud solutions. I have over three years of experience in entrepreneurship, business development, and venture analysis, working with startups (including my own), VC firms, and corporations across different sectors and regions. I am passionate about leveraging technology and innovation to create positive social impact and solve global challenges, particularly within the realm of education. I recently graduated from Columbia University with double majors in Economics and Psychology.

Annie (CC ‘22) is a software engineer at Instagram in New York. She works on a team that supports creators by building features to help them succeed. Previously, she had interned at Amazon under Alexa’s AI Foundations org. She was also a head TA of 1004 and TA for AP. As a former participant of Devfest back in her freshman year, she’s excited to see what new projects participants come up with this year!
